Next, we provide the optimal (feedback) strategy of portfolio and consumption in terms of the inverse FL transform $v(x, z, m)$ with $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$ defined by (4.5)-(4.6). We first have

Lemma 4.3. Assume that $\mu_{Z} \geq \eta$ and $\rho>\rho_{0}$. Let $x \mapsto f(x, z, m)$ be the inverse function of $y \mapsto-\hat{v}_{y}(y, z, m)$. Introduce the (feedback) control functions as follows, for $(x, z, m) \in \mathcal{D}$,

$$
\theta^{*}(x, z, m):=-\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{-1} \frac{v_{x}(x, z, m) \mu+\left(v_{x z}-v_{x x}\right)(x, z, m) z \sigma_{Z} \sigma \gamma}{v_{x x}(x, z, m)}
$$

and

$$
c^{*}(x, z, m):= \begin{cases}\lambda m, & 0 \leq x<F_{1}(z, m) \\ (f(x, z, m))^{\frac{1}{p-1}}, & F_{1}(z, m) \leq x<F_{2}(z, m) \\ m, & F_{2}(z, m) \leq x \leq F_{3}(z, m)\end{cases}
$$

For $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3} \backslash \mathcal{D}$, we introduce that $\theta^{*}(x, z, m):=\theta^{*}\left(x, z, m^{*}(x, z)\right)$ and $c^{*}(x, z, m):=$ $c^{*}\left(x, z, m^{*}(x, z)\right)=m^{*}(x, z)$. Then, there exist positive constants $\left(M_{\theta}, M_{c}\right)$ such that, for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$,

$$
\left|\theta^{*}(x, z, m)\right| \leq M_{\theta}(1+x+z), \quad\left|c^{*}(x, z, m)\right| \leq M_{c}(1+x+m)
$$

Proof. It follows from (4.10) and Lemma 4.1 that $\left|c^{*}(x, z, m)\right| \leq M_{c}(1+x+m)$ for some positive constant $M_{c}$. In lieu of the duality representation, we have $x=-\hat{v}_{y}(f(x, z, m), z, m)$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\theta^{*}(x, z, m)\right| \leq\left|\left(\sigma \sigma^{T}\right)^{-1} \mu\right|\left|\frac{v_{x}(x, z, m)}{v_{x x}(x, z, m)}\right|+\left|\sigma_{Z} \gamma^{T} \sigma^{-1}\right|\left|\frac{z v_{x z}(x, z, m)}{v_{x x}(x, z, m)}\right|+\left|\sigma_{Z} \gamma^{T} \sigma^{-1}\right| z \\
& =\left|\left(\sigma \sigma^{T}\right)^{-1} \mu\right| f(x, z, m) \hat{v}_{y y}(f(x, z, m), z, m)+\left|\sigma_{Z} \gamma^{T} \sigma^{-1}\right|\left|z \hat{v}_{y z}(f(x, z, m), z, m)\right|+\left|\sigma_{Z} \gamma^{T} \sigma^{-1}\right| z
\end{aligned}
$$

For $y^{*}(m) \leq y \leq m^{p-1}, z>0$ and $m \geq \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}$, we have

$$
-\frac{\left|z \hat{v}_{y z}(y, z, m)\right|}{\hat{v}_{y}(y, z, m)}=\frac{z\left(\beta^{1-\kappa} y^{\kappa-1}-1\right)}{-\frac{1}{\beta} C_{5}(m)+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} C_{6}(m) y^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}-\frac{m}{\alpha+\rho} \ln \frac{y}{\beta}-\frac{m}{\alpha+\rho}+z\left(\beta^{1-\kappa} y^{\kappa-1}-1\right)} \leq 1
$$

which results in $\left|z \hat{v}_{y z}(f(x, z, m), z, m)\right| \leq x$. For $y^{*}(m) \leq y \leq m^{p-1}$ and $z>0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\frac{y \hat{v}_{y y}(y, z, m)}{\hat{v}_{y}(y, z, m)} & \leq \frac{\frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} C_{6}(m) y^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}+\frac{m}{\alpha+\rho}}{-\frac{1}{\beta} C_{5}(m)+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} C_{6}(m) y^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}-\frac{m}{\alpha+\rho} \ln \frac{y}{\beta}-\frac{m}{\alpha+\rho}}+\frac{z \beta^{1-\kappa}(1-\kappa) y^{\kappa-1}}{z\left(\beta^{1-\kappa} y^{\kappa-1}-1\right)} \\
& \leq \frac{\frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}\left(y^{*}(m)\right)^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}+\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho}}{-\frac{1}{\beta} \frac{C_{5}(m)}{m}+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}\left(m^{p-1}\right)^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}-\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho} \ln \frac{m^{p-1}}{\beta}-\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho}}+(1-\kappa)
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}\left(y^{*}(m)\right)^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}} \\
& \quad=\frac{1}{m} e^{\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha} r^{*}(m)} \int_{m}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{\alpha \beta} u^{p-1} e^{-\frac{\rho}{\alpha} r^{*}(u)}-\frac{\rho}{\alpha(\alpha+\rho)} e^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha} r^{*}(u)}\right) d u
\end{aligned}
$$

where $r^{*}(m)=\ln \left(\beta / y^{*}(m)\right)$ for $m \geq \frac{1}{\lambda} \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}$ and $y^{*}(m)$ is the unique solution to Eq. (3.5). Dividing by $r^{*}(m)$ and letting $m \rightarrow \infty$ on both sides of (3.5), we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\lim _{m \rightarrow \infty} \frac{e^{r^{*}(m)-\ln m^{1-p}}+\ln m^{(1-p) \beta(1-\lambda)}}{r^{*}(m)}=\lim _{m \rightarrow \infty} \frac{e^{\tilde{r}(m)}+\ln m^{(1-p) \beta(1-\lambda)}}{\tilde{r}(m)+\ln m^{1-p}} \\
=\lim _{m \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1+e^{-\tilde{r}(m)+\ln \ln m^{(1-p) \beta(1-\lambda)}}}{e^{-\tilde{r}(m)} \tilde{r}(m)+e^{-\tilde{r}(m)+\ln \ln m^{1-p}}}=\beta
\end{gathered}
$$

with $\tilde{r}(m):=r^{*}(m)-\ln m^{1-p}$ for $m \geq \frac{1}{\lambda} \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}$. It is easy to verify that $\lim _{m \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\tilde{r}(m)+\ln \ln m^{1-p}}<$ $\infty$ and $\lim _{m \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\tilde{r}(m)+\ln \ln m^{(1-p) \beta(1-\lambda)}}<\infty$, which together with (4.14) yields that

$$
\lim _{m \rightarrow \infty}\left(r^{*}(m)-\ln m^{1-p}-\ln \ln m^{\beta(1-p) \lambda}\right)=0
$$

Hence, one can find a constant $M_{0} \geq \frac{1}{\lambda} \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}$ such that, for $m \geq M_{0}$,

$$
\ln m^{1-p}+\ln \ln m^{\beta(1-p) \lambda}-\frac{\alpha}{4 \rho} \leq r^{*}(m) \leq \ln m^{1-p}+\ln \ln m^{\beta(1-p) \lambda}+\frac{\alpha}{4 \rho}
$$

Then, it follows from (4.13) and $\rho>\rho_{0}$ that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{1}{p}} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}\left(y^{*}(m)\right)^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}+\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho} \leq \frac{1}{\alpha+\rho}+\frac{1}{m} e^{\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}\left(\ln m^{1-p}+\ln \ln m^{\beta(1-p) \lambda}+\frac{\alpha}{4 \rho}\right)} \\
& \quad \times \int_{m}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{\alpha \beta} u^{p-1} e^{-\frac{\rho}{\alpha}\left(\ln u^{1-p}+\ln \ln u^{\beta(1-p) \lambda}-\frac{\alpha}{4 \rho}\right)}-\frac{\rho}{\alpha(\alpha+\rho)} e^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}\left(\ln u^{1-p}+\ln \ln u^{\beta(1-p) \lambda}+\frac{\alpha}{4 \rho}\right)}\right) d u \\
& \leq m^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}-1} \int_{m}^{\infty}\left(\frac{(1-p) \lambda}{\alpha} e^{\frac{\alpha}{4 \rho}+\frac{1}{\beta}} u^{-\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}} \ln u-\frac{\rho}{\alpha(\alpha+\rho)} u^{-\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}\right) d u+\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho}
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand, for $m \geq M_{0}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&-\frac{1}{\beta} \frac{C_{5}(m)}{m}+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}\left(m^{p-1}\right)^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}-\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho} \ln \frac{m^{p-1}}{\beta}-\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho} \\
&=(1-\lambda)\left(\frac{1-p}{\alpha+\rho}+\frac{\alpha}{(\alpha+\rho)^{2}}\right)+\frac{\lambda \ln \beta(\lambda m)^{1-p}}{\alpha+\rho}-\frac{\rho}{\alpha \beta} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m} \\
&-\frac{\alpha^{2} \beta^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}}{(\alpha+\rho)^{2}(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)}\left(\lambda^{\frac{\alpha p-(1-p) \rho}{\alpha}}-1\right) m^{-\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} C_{6}(m) m^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

In view of the fact that $\lim _{m \rightarrow \infty} \lambda \ln \beta(\lambda m)^{1-p}=\infty$ and that

$$
\lim _{m \rightarrow \infty}\left[C_{6}(m) m^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}-1}-\frac{\rho}{\alpha \beta} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}-\frac{\alpha^{2} \beta^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}}{(\alpha+\rho)^{2}(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)}\left(\lambda^{\frac{\alpha p-(1-p) \rho}{\alpha}}-1\right) m^{-\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}\right]=0
$$

there exists a constant $M_{1} \geq M_{0} \vee 1$ such that, for all $m \geq M_{1}$,

$$
\frac{\lambda \ln \beta(\lambda m)^{1-p}}{\alpha+\rho}+C_{6}(m) m^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}-1}-\frac{\rho}{\alpha \beta} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}
$$

$$
-\frac{\alpha^{2} \beta^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}}{(\alpha+\rho)^{2}(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)}\left(\lambda^{\frac{\alpha p-(1-p) \rho}{\alpha}}-1\right) m^{-\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}} \geq \frac{\alpha+\rho}{(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)^{2}}
$$

This, combining with (4.17), implies that, for all $m \geq M_{1}$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
-\frac{1}{\beta} \frac{C_{5}(m)}{m}+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}\left(m^{p-1}\right)^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}-\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho} \ln \frac{m^{p-1}}{\beta}-\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho} \\
\geq(1-\lambda)\left[\frac{1-p}{\alpha+\rho}+\frac{\alpha}{(\alpha+\rho)^{2}}\right]+\frac{\alpha+\rho}{(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)^{2}}
\end{gathered}
$$

Using (4.12), (4.16) and (4.18), one can deduce that, for all $m \geq M_{1}$,

$$
-\frac{y \hat{v}_{y y}(y, z, m)}{\hat{v}_{y}(y, z, m)} \leq \frac{1}{(1-\lambda)(1-p)}+\lambda(1-p)^{2} e^{\frac{\alpha}{4 p}+\frac{1}{2}}
$$

On the other hand, for $y^{*}(m) \leq y \leq m^{p-1}, \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}} \leq m \leq M_{1}$ and $z>0$, we have

$$
y \hat{v}_{y y}(y, z, m) \leq \frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} C_{6}\left(\beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}\right)\left(y^{*}\left(M_{1}\right)\right)^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}+\frac{M_{1}}{\alpha+\rho}-\hat{v}_{y}(y, z, m)(1-\kappa)
$$

We deduce from (4.19) and (4.20) that, for some positive constant $M_{o}$ depending on $(\rho, \mu, \sigma, p, \lambda, \beta)$ and $\forall(x, z, m) \in\left\{(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}: y^{*}(m) \leq v_{x}(x, z, m)<m^{p-1}, m \geq \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}\right\}$, it holds that

$$
f(x, z, m) \hat{v}_{y y}(f(x, z, m), z, m) \leq M_{o}+\left(\frac{1}{(1-\lambda)(1-p)}+\lambda(1-p)^{2} e^{\frac{\alpha}{4 p}+\frac{1}{2}}\right) x
$$

In what follows, let $M_{o}>0$ be a generic positive constant depending on $(\rho, \mu, \sigma, p, \lambda, \beta)$ that may differ from line to line. For $m^{p-1} \leq y \leq(\lambda m)^{p-1}, m \geq M_{0}$ and $z>0$, we have

$$
-\frac{y \hat{v}_{y y}(y, z, m)}{\hat{v}_{y}(y, z, m)} \leq \frac{\frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m} m^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}+\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho}}{-\frac{1}{\beta} \frac{C_{3}(m)}{m}+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{4}(m)}{m}(\lambda m)^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}+\frac{(1-p)^{2}}{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p} \lambda}+1-\kappa
$$

Note that, for $m \geq M_{0}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\frac{1}{\beta} \frac{C_{3}(m)}{m}+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{4}(m)}{m}(\lambda m)^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}+\frac{(1-p)^{2}}{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p} \lambda \\
& =-\frac{\alpha^{2} \beta^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}}{(\alpha+\rho)^{2}(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)}\left(\lambda^{\frac{\alpha p-(1-p) \rho}{\alpha}}-1\right) m^{-\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}-\frac{((2-p) \alpha+\rho(1-p)) \lambda}{(\alpha+\rho)^{2}} \\
& -\frac{\rho}{\alpha \beta} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}-\frac{\alpha^{2} \beta^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}}{(\alpha+\rho)^{2}(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)}\left(\lambda^{\frac{\alpha p-(1-p) \rho}{\alpha}}-1\right)+\frac{(1-p)^{2} \lambda}{\rho(1-p)-\alpha \rho} \\
& +\frac{\rho}{\alpha} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}(\lambda m)^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}+\frac{\lambda}{\alpha+\rho} \ln \beta(\lambda m)^{1-p}
\end{aligned}
$$

and $\lim _{m \rightarrow \infty} C_{6}(m) m^{\frac{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p}{\alpha}}=0, \lim _{m \rightarrow \infty} \ln \beta(\lambda m)^{1-p}=\infty$. Then, there exists a constant $M_{2} \geq \frac{1}{\lambda} \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}$ such that, for all $m \geq M_{2}$,

$$
-\frac{1}{\beta} \frac{C_{3}(m)}{m}+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{4}(m)}{m}(\lambda m)^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}+\frac{(1-p)^{2}}{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p} \lambda \geq 1
$$

and

$$
\frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m} m^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}+\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho} \leq 1
$$

Therefore, thanks to (4.22)-(4.24), we obtain that

$$
-\frac{y \hat{v}_{y y}(y, z, m)}{\hat{v}_{y}(y, z, m)} \leq 2-\kappa, \quad \forall m \geq M_{2}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
y \hat{v}_{y y}(y, z, m) \leq & \frac{\alpha^{2}}{(\alpha+\rho)^{2}(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)} M_{2}+\frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} C_{6}\left(\beta^{\frac{1}{\rho-1}}\right) M_{2}^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}} \\
& +\frac{1-p}{(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p) M_{2}}-\hat{v}_{y}(y, z, m)(1-\kappa), \quad \forall \beta^{\frac{1}{\rho-1}} \leq m \leq M_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from (4.25) and (4.26) that, for any $(x, z, m) \in\left\{(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}: m^{p-1} \leq v_{x}(x, z, m)<\right.$ $(\lambda m)^{p-1}, m \geq \beta^{\frac{1}{\rho-1}}\}$,

$$
f(x, z, m) \hat{v}_{y y}(f(x, z, m), z, m) \leq M_{o}+2 x
$$

Finally, for $(\lambda m)^{p-1} \leq y \leq \frac{\beta}{2}, m \geq \frac{1}{\lambda}\left(\frac{\beta}{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{\rho-1}}$ and $z>0$, it holds that

$$
y \hat{v}_{y y}(y, z, m)=\frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} C_{2}(m) y^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}+\frac{\lambda}{\alpha+\rho}+z \beta^{1-\kappa}(1-\kappa) y^{\kappa-1}
$$

Note that the following estimation holds:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} C_{2}(m) y^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}+z \beta^{1-\kappa}(1-\kappa) y^{\kappa-1}}{-\frac{1}{\beta} C_{1}(m)+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} C_{2}(m) y^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}-\frac{\lambda m}{\alpha+\rho} \ln \frac{y}{\beta}+\frac{\lambda m}{\alpha+\rho}+z\left(\beta^{1-\kappa} y^{\kappa-1}-1\right)} \\
& \leq \frac{\frac{\alpha\left(\lambda-\lambda^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}\right)}{(\alpha+\rho)(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)}+\frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}(\lambda m)^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}}{-\frac{1}{\beta} \frac{C_{1}(m)}{m}+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{2}(m)}{m}\left(\frac{\beta}{2}\right)^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}+\frac{\lambda}{\alpha+\rho} \ln 2+\frac{\lambda}{\alpha+\rho}}+\frac{1-\kappa}{1-(\beta / 2)^{1-\kappa}}
\end{aligned}
$$

In view of the fact $\lim _{m \rightarrow \infty} C_{6}(m) m^{\frac{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p}{\alpha}}=0$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\frac{1}{\beta} \frac{C_{1}(m)}{m}+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{2}(m)}{m}\left(\frac{\beta}{2}\right)^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}+\frac{\lambda}{\alpha+\rho} \ln 2+\frac{\lambda}{\alpha+\rho} \\
& \quad=\frac{\alpha^{2} \beta^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}\left(\lambda^{\frac{\alpha p-\rho(1-p)}{\alpha}}-1\right) m^{-\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}}}{(\alpha+\rho)^{2}(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)}\left(\left(\frac{\beta}{2}\right)^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}-1\right)-\frac{\rho}{\alpha \beta} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}+\frac{\lambda(2+\ln 2)}{\alpha+\rho}
\end{aligned}
$$

there exists a constant $M_{3} \geq \frac{1}{\lambda} \beta^{\frac{1}{\rho-1}}$ such that, for all $m \geq M_{3}$,

$$
\frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{6}(m)}{m}(\lambda m)^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-p)}{\alpha}} \leq \frac{\lambda}{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p}
$$

and

$$
-\frac{1}{\beta} \frac{C_{1}(m)}{m}+\frac{\rho}{\alpha} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \frac{C_{2}(m)}{m}\left(\frac{\beta}{2}\right)^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}+\frac{\lambda}{\alpha+\rho} \ln 2+\frac{\lambda}{\alpha+\rho} \geq \frac{1}{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p}
$$

As a consequence, for all $m \geq M_{3}$,

$$
y \hat{v}_{y y}(y, z, m) \leq \frac{\lambda}{\alpha+\rho}-\left(2 \lambda+\frac{1-\kappa}{1-(\beta / 2)^{1-\kappa}}\right) \hat{v}_{y}(y, z, m)
$$

For $(\lambda m)^{p-1} \leq y \leq \frac{\beta}{2}, \frac{1}{\lambda}\left(\frac{\beta}{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{p-1}} \leq m \leq M_{3}$ and $z>0$, we arrive at

$$
\begin{aligned}
y \hat{v}_{y y}(y, z, m) \leq & \frac{\lambda\left(\lambda-\lambda^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-\rho)}{\alpha}}\right)}{(\alpha+\rho)(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)} M_{3}+\frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2}} \beta^{\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} C_{6}\left(\frac{1}{\lambda} \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}\right)\left(\lambda M_{3}\right)^{\frac{(\alpha+\rho)(1-\rho)}{\alpha}} \\
& +\frac{\lambda}{\alpha+\rho}-\hat{v}_{y}(y, z, m)(1-\kappa)
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\frac{\beta}{2} \leq y \leq \beta, m \geq \frac{1}{\lambda} \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}$ and $z>0$, one gets that

$$
y \hat{v}_{y y}(y, z, m) \leq \frac{(\alpha+\rho) \rho}{\alpha^{2} \beta} C_{2}\left(\frac{1}{\lambda} \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}\right) 2^{\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\alpha}}+\frac{\lambda}{\alpha+\rho}+z(1-\kappa)
$$

In view of (4.29)-(4.31), it holds that, for any $(x, z, m) \in\left\{(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3} ;(\lambda m)^{p-1} \leq v_{x}(x, z, m) \leq\right.$ $\beta, m \geq \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}\}$,

$$
f(x, z, m) \hat{v}_{y y}(f(x, z, m), z, m) \leq M_{o}+\left(2 \lambda+\frac{1-\kappa}{1-(\beta / 2)^{1-\kappa}}\right) x
$$

Then, by (4.21), (4.27) and (4.32), we deduce that $\left|\theta^{*}(x, z, m)\right| \leq M_{\theta}(1+x+z)$ for some positive constant $M_{\theta}$.

Now, we are ready to show the verification result, which proves that the function $v(x, z, m)$ introduced by (4.5)-(4.6) is indeed the value function for problem (2.10) and the admissible strategy induced by the feedback control functions $\theta^{*}(x, z, m)$ and $c^{*}(x, z, m)$ defined by (4.9) is the optimal strategy of investment and consumption.
Theorem 4.4. Let $\mu_{Z} \geq \eta$ and $\rho>\rho_{0}$ with $\rho_{0}$ given by (3.23). Recall the function $v(x, z, m)$ introduced by (4.5)-(4.6) and the feedback control function $\left(\theta^{*}(x, z, m), c^{*}(x, z, m)\right)$ given by (4.9). Consider the controlled state process $\left(X^{*}, Z, M^{*}\right)=\left(X_{t}^{*}, Z_{t}, M_{t}^{*}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ that obeys the following reflected $S D E$, for $(t, x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{4}$,

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
X_{t}^{*}= & x+\int_{0}^{t}\left(\theta^{*}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)\right)^{\top} \mu d s+\int_{0}^{t}\left(\theta^{*}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)\right)^{\top} \sigma d W_{s} \\
& -\int_{0}^{t} c^{*}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d s-\int_{0}^{t} \mu_{Z} Z_{s} d s-\int_{0}^{t} \sigma_{Z} Z_{s} d W_{s}^{\gamma}+L_{t}^{X^{*}} \\
M_{t}^{*}= & \max \left\{m, \sup _{s \in[0, t]} m^{*}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}\right)\right\} \\
Z_{t}= & z+\int_{0}^{t} \mu_{z} Z_{s} d s+\int_{0}^{t} \sigma_{Z} Z_{s} d W_{s}^{\gamma}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

with $L_{0}^{X^{*}}=0$ and $M_{0}^{*}=m$. Define $\theta_{t}^{*}=\theta^{*}\left(X_{t}^{*}, Z_{t}, M_{t}^{*}\right)$ and $c_{t}^{*}=c^{*}\left(X_{t}^{*}, Z_{t}, M_{t}^{*}\right)$ for all $t \geq 0$. Then, the strategy pair $\left(\theta^{*}, c^{*}\right)=\left(\theta_{t}^{*}, c_{t}^{*}\right)_{t \geq 0} \in \mathbb{U}^{r}$ is an optimal investment-consumption strategy in the sense that, for all admissible $(\theta, c) \in \mathbb{U}^{r}$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} U\left(c_{t}\right) d t-\beta \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d L_{t}^{X}\right] \leq v(x, z, m), \quad \forall(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}
$$

and the equality holds when $(\theta, c)=\left(\theta^{*}, c^{*}\right)$.
Proof. We first show the validity of the inequality (4.34). For any $(\theta, c) \in \mathbb{U}^{r}$, let $\left(X_{t}, Z_{t}, M_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ be the corresponding state process with initial data $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$. Fix $T>0$. It follows from Itô's formula that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& e^{-\rho T} v\left(X_{T}, Z_{T}, m\right)+\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s} U\left(c_{s}\right) d s \\
& \quad=v(x, z, m)+\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s} v_{x}\left(X_{s}, Z_{s}, m\right) \theta_{s}^{\top} \sigma d W_{s}+\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s} \sigma_{Z} Z_{s}\left(v_{z}-v_{x}\right)\left(X_{s}, Z_{s}, m\right) d W_{s}^{\gamma} \\
& \quad+\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s} v_{x}\left(X_{s}, Z_{s}, m\right) d L_{s}^{X}+\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s}\left(\mathcal{L}^{\theta_{s}, c_{s}} v-\rho v\right)\left(X_{s}, Z_{s}, m\right) d s
\end{aligned}
$$

where, for $(\theta, c) \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}_{+}$, the operator $\mathcal{L}^{\theta, c}$ acting on $C^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}\right)$ is defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{L}^{\theta, c} g:=\ & \theta^{\top} \mu g_{x}+\frac{1}{2} \theta^{\top} \sigma \sigma^{\top} \theta g_{x x}+\theta^{\top} \sigma \gamma \sigma_{Z} z\left(g_{x z}-g_{x x}\right)+U(c)-c v_{g} \\
& -\sigma_{Z}^{2} z^{2} g_{x z}+\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{Z}^{2} z^{2}\left(g_{x x}+g_{z z}\right)+\mu_{Z} z\left(g_{z}-g_{x}\right), \quad \forall g \in C^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$ and $(\theta, c) \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \times[\lambda m, m]$, Lemma 4.2 implies that $\left(\mathcal{L}^{\theta, c} v-\right.$ $\rho v)(x, z, m) \leq 0$ and $v_{x}(0, z, m)=\beta$. Consequently, taking the expectation on both sides of (4.35), we deduce

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\rho T} v\left(X_{T}, Z_{T}, m\right)\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho t} U\left(c_{t}\right) d t-\beta \int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho t} d L_{t}^{X}\right] \leq v(x, z, m)
$$

Using Lemma 4.2 again, we arrive at $v_{x}(x, z, m) \geq 0$ and $\left|v_{z}(x, z, m)\right| \leq \beta / \kappa$ for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$. Thus, one gets, for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$,

$$
v(x, z, m) \geq v(0, z, m) \geq v(0,0, m)-\frac{\beta}{\kappa} z
$$

By letting $T \rightarrow \infty$ in (4.36), we obtain from (4.37), Dominated Convergence Theorem (DCT), the Monotone Convergence Theorem (MCT) and $\rho>\mu_{Z}$ that

$$
\begin{aligned}
v(x, z, m) & \geq \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} U\left(c_{t}\right) d t-\beta \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d L_{t}^{X}\right]+\liminf _{T \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\rho T} v\left(X_{T}, Z_{T}, m\right)\right] \\
& \geq \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} U\left(c_{t}\right) d t-\beta \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d L_{t}^{X}\right]+\liminf _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T}\left\{v(0,0, m)-\frac{\beta}{\kappa} \mathbb{E}\left[Z_{T}\right]\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} U\left(c_{t}\right) d t-\beta \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d L_{t}^{X}\right]
$$

Next, we prove that the equality in (4.34) holds true when $(\theta, c)=\left(\theta^{*}, c^{*}\right)$. It follows from Lemma A. 1 that $\left(\theta^{*}, c^{*}\right) \in \mathbb{U}^{r}$. We next show that the following transversality condition holds:

$$
\limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\rho T} v\left(X_{T}^{*}, Z_{T}, M_{T}^{*}\right)\right] \leq 0
$$

To this end, we introduce an auxiliary dual process $\left(Y_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ with $Y_{t}=v_{x}\left(X_{t}^{*}, Z_{t}, M_{t}^{*}\right)$ for all $t \geq 0$ to facilitate the proof of the above convergence. By Lemma A. 2 in Appendix A, we know that $Y_{t}$ taking values on $(0, \beta]$ satisfies the SDE with reflection that

$$
d Y_{t}=\rho Y_{t} d t-\mu^{\top} \sigma^{-1} Y_{t} d W_{t}-d L_{t}^{Y}
$$

Here, the process $L=\left(L_{t}^{Y}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ is a continuous and non-decreasing process (with $L_{t}^{Y}=0$ ) that increases on the time set $\left\{t \geq 0 ; Y_{t}=\beta\right\}$ only. Moreover, it follows from the dual relationship that

$$
v\left(X_{t}^{*}, Z_{t}, M_{t}^{*}\right)=\hat{v}\left(Y_{t}, Z_{z}, M_{t}^{*}\right)+X_{t}^{*} Y_{t}=\hat{v}\left(Y_{t}, Z_{z}, M_{t}^{*}\right)-Y_{t} \hat{v}_{y}\left(Y_{t}, Z_{z}, M_{t}^{*}\right), \quad \forall t \geq 0
$$

Note that $\frac{\partial\left(\hat{v}-y \hat{v}_{y}\right)}{\partial y}(y, z, m)=-\hat{v}_{y y}(y, z, m)<0$ for all $(y, z, m) \in\left[y^{*}(m), \beta\right] \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times\left[\beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}, \infty\right)$. It follows that the function $\hat{v}-y \hat{v}_{y}$ is strictly decreasing with respect to $y$. Thus, it suffices to consider the case $y=y^{*}(m) \leq m^{p-1}$. Then, by Proposition 3.1 and (4.16), we have that

$$
\hat{v}(y, z, m)-y \hat{v}_{y}(y, z, m) \leq K C_{6}(m) y^{-\frac{\rho}{\alpha}} \leq K m y \leq y^{\frac{1}{p-1}} y=K y^{\frac{p}{p-1}}
$$

where $K$ is a positive constant that might be different from line to line. For the discount rate $\rho>\rho_{0}$, we have from (4.41), (4.42) and Lemma A. 3 in Appendix A, that

$$
\limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\rho T} v\left(X_{T}^{*}, Z_{T}, M_{T}^{*}\right)\right] \leq K \limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T} \mathbb{E}\left[\overbrace{Y_{T}^{\frac{p}{p-1}}^{\frac{p}{p-1}}\right]=0
$$

which gives the desired transversality condition (4.39).
Now, for any $T>0$, using Itô's rule, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& e^{-\rho T} v\left(X_{T}^{*}, Z_{T}, M_{T}^{*}\right)+\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s} U\left(c_{s}^{*}\right) d s \\
& \quad=v(x, z, m)+\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s} v_{x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)\left(\theta_{s}^{*}\right)^{\top} \sigma d W_{s}+\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s} \sigma_{Z} Z_{s}\left(v_{z}-v_{x}\right)\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d W_{s}^{\gamma} \\
& \quad+\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s} v_{x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d L_{s}^{X}+\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s}\left(\mathcal{L}_{\sigma_{s}^{*}, c_{s}^{*}}^{\theta_{s}^{*}, c_{s}^{*}} v-\rho v\right)\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d s \\
& \quad+\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s} v_{m}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d M_{s}^{*, c}+\sum_{0<s \leq T} e^{-\rho s}\left(v\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)-v\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s-}^{*}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $M^{*, c}$ is the continuous part of $M^{*}$. Note that, the process $M^{*}$ can only jump at time $t=0$ if $m<m^{*}(x, z)$, then $\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)$ stays in the domain $\mathcal{D}=\left\{(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3} ; x \leq F_{3}(z, m)\right\}$ for all

$s>0$. Then, it follows from $M_{s}^{*, c}$ increases if and only if $M_{s}^{*, c}=m^{*}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}\right), v_{m}\left(x, z, m^{*}(x, z)\right)=$ 0 and (4.6) holds, we then deduce

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho s} v_{m}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d M_{s}^{*, c}+\sum_{0<s \leq T} e^{-\rho s}\left(v\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)-v\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s-}^{*}\right)\right) \\
\quad=v\left(X_{0}^{*}, Z_{0}, M_{0}^{*}\right)-v\left(X_{0}^{*}, Z_{0}, M_{0}^{*}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, by taking the expectation on both sides of Eq. (4.44), it follows from $\left(\mathcal{L}^{\theta^{*}, c^{*}} v-\rho v\right)(x, z, m)=$ 0 and $v_{x}(0, z, m)=\beta$ for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathcal{D}$ that

$$
v(x, z, m)=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\rho T} v\left(X_{T}^{*}, Z_{T}^{*}, M_{T}^{*}\right)\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho t} U\left(c_{t}^{*}\right) d t-\beta \int_{0}^{T} e^{-\rho t} d L_{t}^{X^{*}}\right]
$$

Letting $T \rightarrow \infty$ in (4.45). We get from the inequality (4.39), DCT and MCT that

$$
\begin{aligned}
v(x, z, m) & \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} U\left(c_{t}^{*}\right) d t-\beta \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d L_{t}^{X^{*}}\right] \\
& \leq \sup _{(\theta, c) \in \mathbb{U}^{r}} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} U\left(c_{t}\right) d t-\beta \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d L_{t}^{X}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining (4.38) with (4.46), we conclude that the inequality in (4.46) holds as an equality.
Remark 4.5. Recall that Proposition 3.1 provides an explicit classical solution to the dual PDE (3.4) but not verify if the inequality constraint $\hat{v}_{m}(y, z, m) \leq 0$ is satisfied. It requires quite tedious calculations due to the implicit expression of $y^{*}(m)$ and the coefficient functions $C_{i}(m)$ for $i=1, \ldots, 6$. In turn, Lemma 4.2 does not show that the value function defined by (4.5)(4.6) satisfies the HJB-VI (2.12) as it remains to prove $v_{m}(x, z, m) \leq 0$ for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$. However, it becomes an obvious result after Theorem 4.4 in view of definition of admissible set $\mathbb{U}^{r}$ and the value function given by (2.10).

The following lemma shows that the expectation of the total optimal discounted capital injection is always finite and positive.

Lemma 4.6. Let the assumptions of Theorem 4.4 hold. Consider the optimal strategy of investment and consumption $\left(\theta^{*}, c^{*}\right)=\left(\theta_{t}^{*}, c_{t}^{*}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ given in Theorem 4.4. Then, it holds that
(i) The expectation of the discounted total capital injection under the optimal strategy $\left(\theta^{*}, c^{*}\right)$ is finite that, for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d A_{t}^{*}\right] \leq \frac{1}{|p|} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} Y_{t}^{\frac{p}{\rho-1}} d t\right]-v(x, z, m)<+\infty
$$

(ii) The expectation of the discounted total capital injection under the optimal strategy $\left(\theta^{*}, c^{*}\right)$ is strictly positive that, for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times(0, \infty)^{2}$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d A_{t}^{*}\right] \geq \max \left\{z \frac{1-\kappa}{\kappa}\left(1+\frac{x}{z}\right)^{\frac{\kappa}{\kappa-1}}, \frac{\lambda m}{\alpha+\rho} e^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\lambda m} x}\right\}>0
$$

Here, the optimal capital injection under the optimal strategy $\left(\theta^{*}, c^{*}\right)$ is given by $A_{t}^{*}=0 \vee$ $\sup _{s \leq t}\left(Z_{s}-V_{s}^{\theta^{*}, c^{*}}\right)$ for $t \geq 0$.

Proof. We first prove the item (i). For $(\mathrm{v}, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$, by applying (2.6), we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d A_{t}^{*}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} U\left(c_{t}^{*}\right) d t\right]-v(x, z, m)
$$

with $x=(\mathrm{v}-z)^{+}$by Lemma 2.2. By uisng the dual relationship, we have that

$$
U\left(c^{*}(x, z, m)\right)=\frac{\left(c^{*}(x, z, m)\right)^{p}}{p}=\frac{1}{p} \times \begin{cases}\lambda^{p} m^{p}, & (\lambda m)^{p-1}<y \leq \beta \\ y^{\frac{p}{p-1}}, & m^{p-1}<y \leq(\lambda m)^{p-1} \\ m^{p}, & y^{*}(m) \leq y \leq m^{p-1} \\ \left(m^{*}(y)\right)^{p}, & y<y^{*}(m)\end{cases}
$$

where $y=y(x, z, m)=v_{x}(x, z, m)$ and $y \rightarrow m^{*}(y)$ is the inverse function of $m \rightarrow y^{*}(m)$. From (4.50), we can deduce that $U\left(c^{*}(x, z, m)\right) \leq y^{\frac{p}{p-1}} /|p|$ for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$. Then, it follows from Lemma A. 2 and the proof of Lemma A. 3 in Appendix A that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} U\left(c_{t}^{*}\right) d t\right] \leq \frac{1}{|p|} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} Y_{t}^{\frac{p}{p-1}} d t\right]<+\infty
$$

Then, the desired result (4.47) follows from (4.51).
Next, we prove the item (ii). For any admissible portfolio $\theta=\left(\theta_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$, we introduce, for all $t \geq 0$

$$
\tilde{V}_{t}^{\theta}=\mathrm{v}+\int_{0}^{t} \theta_{s}^{\top} \mu d s+\int_{0}^{t} \theta_{s}^{\top} \sigma d W_{s}, \quad \tilde{A}_{t}^{\theta}=0 \vee \sup _{s \leq t}\left(Z_{s}-\tilde{V}_{s}^{\theta}\right)
$$

Note that $c_{t}^{*}>0$ for all $t \geq 0$. It follows from (2.2) and (4.52) that $\tilde{V}_{t}^{\theta^{*}} \geq V_{t}^{\theta^{*}, c^{*}}$ for all $t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$, and hence

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d A_{t}^{*}\right]>\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d \tilde{A}_{t}^{\theta^{*}}\right] \geq \inf _{\theta} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d \tilde{A}_{t}^{\theta}\right]=: \tilde{\mathrm{w}}(\mathrm{v}, z)
$$

It is not difficult to check that, for all $(\mathrm{v}, z) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times(0, \infty)$,

$$
\tilde{\mathrm{w}}(\mathrm{v}, z)=z \frac{1-\kappa}{\kappa}\left(1+\frac{(\mathrm{v}-z)^{+}}{z}\right)^{\frac{\kappa}{\kappa-1}}
$$

On the other hand, for any admissible portfolio $\theta=\left(\theta_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$, let us consider an auxiliary process

$$
\hat{V}_{t}^{\theta}=\mathrm{v}+\int_{0}^{t} \theta_{s}^{\top} \mu d s+\int_{0}^{t} \theta_{s}^{\top} \sigma d W_{s}-\lambda m t, \quad \hat{A}_{t}^{\theta}=0 \vee \sup _{s \leq t}\left(-\hat{V}_{s}^{\theta}\right), \quad t \geq 0
$$

Note that $c_{t}^{*} \geq \lambda m$ for all $t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$. Then, it follows from (2.2) and (4.55) that $\hat{V}_{t}^{\theta^{*}} \geq V_{t}^{\theta^{*}, c^{*}}$ for all $t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$, and hence

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d A_{t}^{*}\right]>\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d \hat{A}_{t}^{\theta^{*}}\right] \geq \inf _{\theta} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\rho t} d \hat{A}_{t}^{\theta}\right]=: \hat{\mathrm{w}}(\mathrm{v}, m)
$$

In a similar fashion, we can verify that, for all $(\mathrm{v}, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times(0, \infty)$,

$$
\hat{\mathrm{w}}(\mathrm{v}, m)=\frac{\lambda m}{\alpha+\rho} e^{-\frac{\alpha+\rho}{\lambda m} \mathrm{v}^{+}}
$$

Consequently, combining (4.53), (4.54), (4.56) and (4.57), we complete the proof of the lemma.
The following result shows that when the drawdown constraint vanishes as parameter $\lambda=0$, the stochastic control problem (2.10) simplifies to the optimal tracking problem with no consumption constraint in Bo et al. (2023).

Corollary 4.7. Let assumptions of Theorem 4.4 hold. Then, for fixed $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$, the value function $v(x, z, m)$ given by (2.10). is non-increasing w.r.t. the fraction parameter $\lambda$. In particular, when $\lambda=0$, the value function admits the form given by, for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
v(x, z, m)= & \frac{(1-p)^{2}}{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p} \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}} f(x, z)+\frac{(1-p)^{3}}{p(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)} f(x, z)^{\frac{p}{p-1}}+x f(x, z) \\
& +z\left(f(x, z)-\frac{\beta^{-\kappa+1}}{\kappa} f(x, z)^{\kappa}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the function $f(x, z)$ is uniquely determined by

$$
x=\frac{(1-p)^{2}}{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p}\left(f(x, z)^{\frac{1}{p-1}}-\beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}\right)+z\left(\beta^{-\kappa+1} f(x, z)^{\kappa-1}-1\right)
$$

Furthermore, the optimal feedback control function is given by, for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$,

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\theta^{*}(x, z, m)= & \left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{-1} \mu\left(\frac{1-p}{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p} f(x, z)^{\frac{1}{p-1}}+(1-\kappa) \beta^{-(\kappa-1)} z f(x, z)^{\kappa-1}\right) \\
& +\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{-1} \sigma_{Z} \sigma \gamma z \beta^{-(\kappa-1)} f(x, z)^{\kappa-1} \\
c^{*}(x, z, m)= & f(x, z)^{\frac{1}{p-1}}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

Proof. Denote by $v_{\lambda}(x, z, m)$ the value function and $\mathbb{U}_{\lambda}^{\mathrm{r}}$ the admissible set to highlight the dependence on $\lambda$. Then, for $0 \leq \lambda_{1} \leq \lambda_{2} \leq 1$, it follows from the definition of the admissible set that $\mathbb{U}_{\lambda_{2}}^{\mathrm{r}} \subset \mathbb{U}_{\lambda_{1}}^{\mathrm{r}}$, which yields $v_{\lambda_{2}}(x, z, m) \leq v_{\lambda_{1}}(x, z, m)$ for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$.

When $\lambda=0$, by Proposition 3.1, we have $y^{*}(m)=m^{1-p}$ for $m \geq \beta^{1 /(p-1)}$, and for $(r, z, m) \in$ $\mathbb{R}_{+} \times\left[\beta^{1 /(p-1)}, \infty\right)$, the dual function $\hat{v}(y, z, m)$ becomes

$$
\hat{v}(y, z, m)=\frac{1}{\beta} C_{3}(m) y+\beta^{\frac{p}{\alpha}} C_{4}(m) y^{-\frac{p}{\alpha}}+\frac{(1-p)^{3}}{p(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)} y^{\frac{p}{p-1}}+z\left(y-\frac{\beta^{-\kappa+1}}{\kappa} y^{\kappa}\right)
$$

Moreover, in view of $y^{*}(m)=m^{1-p}$, it holds that

$$
C_{6}(m)=\frac{\alpha^{3} \beta^{-\frac{p}{\alpha}}}{\rho(\alpha+\rho)^{2}(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)} m^{\frac{\alpha p-(1-p) \rho}{\alpha}}
$$

As a result, we can deduce that

$$
C_{3}(m)=\frac{(1-p)^{2}}{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p} \beta^{\frac{p}{p-1}}, \quad C_{4}(m)=0, \quad \forall m \geq \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}}
$$

It follows from (4.61) and (4.62) that

$$
\hat{v}(y, z, m)=\frac{(1-p)^{2}}{\rho(1-p)-\alpha p} \beta^{\frac{1}{p-1}} y+\frac{(1-p)^{3}}{p(\rho(1-p)-\alpha p)} y^{\frac{p}{p-1}}+z\left(y-\frac{\beta^{-\kappa+1}}{\kappa} y^{\kappa}\right)
$$

which is independent of the variable $m$. Then, by Proposition 3.1, Lemma 4.2, Lemma 4.3 and Theorem 4.4, we get the desired results (4.58)-(4.60).

# 5 Numerical Examples 

In this section, we present some numerical examples to illustrate the sensitivity analysis with respect to some model parameters and discuss their financial implications based on the optimal feedback functions and the expected total capital injection obtained in (4.9). To ease the discussions, we only consider the case $d=1$ in all examples.

We first examine the sensitivity of the optimal portfolio, the optimal consumption and the expected capital injection in Figure 2 with respect to the drawdown constraint parameter $\lambda$. Let us fix the model parameters $\rho=2, p=-0.1, \mu=0.01, \sigma=0.02, \beta=2, \mu_{Z}=\sigma_{Z}=0.05, z=$ $10, m=20$ and plot the curves with $\lambda=0,0.05,0.1,0.5,1$, respectively. Being consistent with intuition, when the drawdown constraint parameter $\lambda$ tends to zero, the optimal portfolio, the optimal consumption and the expected capital injection converge to their counterparts of the optimal tracking problem with no consumption constraint (i.e., $\lambda=0$ ) in Bo et al. (2023). More importantly, when the wealth level $x$ is sufficiently high, the optimal consumption in the case of $\lambda>0$ is in fact lower than the unconstrained one with $\lambda=0$, indicating that the drawdown constraint may suppress the consumption behavior in the large wealth regime as the aggressive consumption leads to a larger drawdown reference process. We also observe that the optimal portfolio with $\lambda>0$ is higher than the unconstrained case with $\lambda=0$ so that the drawdown constraint leads to a larger investment amount in the financial market to ensure the drawdown constraint to be sustainable. Figure 2 also shows that a higher capital injection is needed to support a larger consumption drawdown constraint.

We next analyze the sensitivity results with respect to the capital injection cost parameter $\beta$ in Figure 3. Let us fix model parameters $\rho=2, p=-0.1, \mu=0.01, \sigma=0.02, \lambda=0.2, \mu_{Z}=\sigma_{Z}=$ $0.5, z=20, m=6$ and plot the optimal portfolio, the optimal consumption and the expected capital injection with varying $\beta=2,4,30,40,50$. It is not surprising to see in panel (c) of Figure 3 that the larger capital cost parameter $\beta$, the less the capital injection. As the cost parameter $\beta$ increases, the fund manager tends to choose a smaller consumption to reduce the required capital

injection. Meanwhile, the fund manager will strategically reduce the investment in the risk assets to avoid the unnecessary capital injection caused by the volatility of the controlled wealth process.

To understand how the market performance affects the optimal decision in our formulation, we also plot the sensitivity results w.r.t. the excessive returns $\mu=0.004,0.008,0.012,0.016$ in Figure 4 while fixing other model parameters $\rho=2, p=-0.1, \sigma=0.02, \lambda=0.2, \beta=2, \mu_{Z}=\sigma_{Z}=$ $0.5, z=20, m=6$. From the panel (a) of Figure 4, it can be observed that the better the market performs, the more wealth the fund manager is willing to allocate into the market. It is also interesting to see from panel (b) that a higher excessive return $\mu$ results in a larger consumption plan, which is opposite of the result in the classical Merton's problem. This new phenomenon can be explained by the fact that the flexibility in capital injection may increase risk taking attitude of the agent. Particularly, when the market return is good, the necessary amount of capital injection to fulfil the benchmark tracking constraint is significantly reduced. The injected capital might be mainly used to support the more aggressive consumption behavior. Comparing with Merton's formulation under the possible bankruptcy restriction, the capital injection will incentivize the agent to spend more gains from the financial market on consumption when the market performance is good because the agent can strategically inject capital to lift up the wealth whenever it falls down a threshold.

# A Auxiliary Results 

This appendix reports some auxiliary results that will be used to support the proof of some main results in previous sections.

Lemma A.1. Let $\mu_{Z} \geq \eta$ and $\rho>\rho_{0}$. Given the feedback control functions $\theta^{*}(x, z, m)$ and $c^{*}(x, z, m)$ in Theorem 4.4, the system of reflected SDEs (4.33) has a unique strong solution.

Proof. It follows from Lemma 4.2 that $\partial \theta^{*} / \partial h$ and $\partial c^{*} / \partial h$ are both continuous function in $h \in$ $\{x, z, m\}$. For $R>0$, define

$$
K_{R}:=\max _{(x, z, m) \in[0, R]^{3}}\left\{\frac{\partial \theta^{*}}{\partial x} \vee \frac{\partial \theta^{*}}{\partial z} \vee \frac{\partial \theta^{*}}{\partial m} \vee \frac{\partial c^{*}}{\partial x} \vee \frac{\partial c^{*}}{\partial z} \vee \frac{\partial c^{*}}{\partial m}\right\}
$$

Then, for all $\left(x_{1}, z_{1}, m_{1}, x_{2}, z_{2}, m_{2}\right) \in[0, R]^{6}$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|\theta^{*}\left(x_{1}, z_{1}, m_{1}\right)-\theta^{*}\left(x_{2}, z_{2}, m_{2}\right)\right|+\left|c^{*}\left(x_{1}, z_{1}, m_{1}\right)-c^{*}\left(x_{2}, z_{2}, m_{2}\right)\right| \\
\leq K_{R}\left(\left|x_{1}-x_{2}\right|+\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|+\left|m_{1}-m_{2}\right|\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Consequently, we have from (4.33) that $\theta^{*}\left(X_{t}^{*}, Z_{t}, M_{t}^{*}\right)=\theta^{*}\left(X_{t}^{*}, Z_{t}, \max \left\{m, \max _{s \in[0, t]} m^{*}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}\right)\right\}\right)$ for $t \geq 0$. Fix $m \geq 0$ and $t>0$, for any $x, z \in C([0, t])$, let us define

$$
F(t, x, z):=\theta^{*}\left(x_{t}, z_{t}, \max \left\{m, \max _{s \in[0, t]} m^{*}\left(x_{s}, z_{s}\right)\right\}\right)
$$

We then show $F\left(t,\left(x_{s}\right)_{s \in[0, t]},\left(z_{s}\right)_{s \in[0, t]}\right)$ is locally Lipschitz-continuous. To this end, fix $t>0$ and $R_{1}>0$. Let $x, \hat{x}, z, \hat{z} \in C([0, t])$ satisfy $\sup _{s \in[0, t]}\left|h_{t}\right| \leq R_{1}$ with $h \in\{x, \hat{x}, z, \hat{z}\}$. Note that $(x, z) \mapsto m^{*}(x, z)$ given in Lemma 4.1 is in $C^{2}$ in view of the definition of $m^{*}(x, z)$ and the smoothness of $(z, m) \mapsto F_{3}(z, m)$. Then, we have $R_{2}:=\max _{(x, z) \in\left[0, R_{1}\right]^{2}} m^{*}(x, z)<\infty$ and $\tilde{K}_{R_{1}}:=\max _{(x, z) \in\left[0, R_{1}\right]^{2}}\left\{\frac{\partial m^{*}(x, z)}{\partial x} \vee \frac{\partial m^{*}(x, z)}{\partial z}\right\}<\infty$. Introduce $R=\max \left\{R_{1}, R_{2}\right\}$ and $C_{R}=\max \left\{K_{R}, \tilde{K}_{R_{1}}\right\}$. Then, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |F(t, x, z)-F(t, \hat{x}, \hat{z})| \\
& \quad \leq C_{R}\left\{\left|x_{t}-\hat{x}_{t}\right|+\left|z_{t}-\hat{z}_{t}\right|+\left|\max \left\{m, \sup _{s \in[0, t]} m^{*}\left(x_{s}, z_{s}\right)\right\}-\max \left\{m, \sup _{s \in[0, t]} m^{*}\left(\hat{x}_{s}, \hat{z}_{s}\right)\right\}\right|\right\} \\
& \quad \leq 2 C_{R}\left\{\sup _{s \in[0, t]}\left|x_{s}-\hat{x}_{s}\right|+\sup _{s \in[0, t]}\left|z_{s}-\hat{z}_{s}\right|\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Fix $t>0$, and for any $x, z \in C([0, t])$, define $G(t, x, z):=c^{*}\left(x_{t}, z_{t}, \max \left\{m, \sup _{s \in[0, t]} m^{*}\left(x_{s}, z_{s}\right)\right\}\right)$. Then, in a similar fashion, we can obtain the local Lipschitz continuity of $C([0, t])^{2} \ni(x, z) \mapsto$ $G(t, x, z)$ uniformly in $t$. Then, we define the stopping time by $\tau_{n}:=\inf \left\{t \geq 0 ;\left|X_{t}^{*}\right| \geq n\right.$ or $\left|Z_{t}\right| \geq$ $n\}$ with $n>0$. By Theorem 7 in Section 3 of Chapter 5 in Protter (2005), the system of SDEs (4.33) has a unique strong solution on $\left[0, \tau_{n}\right]$. Moreover, by Lemma 4.3 and estimate on moments of SDE, we have that, for any $t>0$,

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\tau_{n}<t\right) \leq \frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\left|X_{\tau_{n} \wedge t}^{*}\right|+\left|Z_{\tau_{n} \wedge t}\right|\right) \mathbf{1}_{\tau_{n}<t}\right] \leq \frac{1}{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|X_{\tau_{n} \wedge t}^{*}\right|+\left|Z_{\tau_{n} \wedge t}\right|\right] \leq \frac{C}{n}(1+x+z)
$$

where $C>0$ is a constant independent of $n$. This implies that $\mathbb{P}\left(\tau_{n}<t\right) \rightarrow 0$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Thus, we can deduce that the system (4.33) has a unique strong solution.

Lemma A.2. Let $\mu_{Z} \geq \eta$ and $\rho>\rho_{0}$. Consider the function $v(x, z, m)$ defined by (4.5)-(4.6) for $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$. It then holds that $v(x, z, m) \in C^{3}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}\right)$. Define the process $\left(Y_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ by $Y_{t}=$ $v_{x}\left(X_{t}^{*}, Z_{t}, M_{t}^{*}\right)$ for all $t \geq 0$. Then, $Y_{t} \in(0, \beta]$ is a reflected process that satisfies the following SDE with reflection:

$$
d Y_{t}=\rho Y_{t} d t-\mu^{\top} \sigma^{-1} Y_{t} d W_{t}-d L_{t}^{Y}
$$

where the process $L=\left(L_{t}^{Y}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ is a continuous and non-decreasing process (with $L_{t}^{Y}=0$ ) which increases on the time set $\left\{t \geq 0 ; Y_{t}=\beta\right\}$ only.

Proof. In view of Proposition 3.1 and (4.5)-(4.6), the function $v(x, z, m)$ is $C^{3}$ in the interior of $\mathcal{D}$ and $\mathbb{R}_{+}^{3} \backslash \mathcal{D}$ and $C^{2}$ in $\mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$. Moreover, for $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3} \backslash \mathcal{D}$, we have from (4.6) and $v_{m}(x, z, m)=$ $v_{m}\left(x, z, m^{*}(x, z)\right)=0$ that

$$
v_{x x x}(x, z, m)=v_{x x x}\left(x, z, m^{*}(x, z)\right)+v_{x x m}\left(x, z, m^{*}(x, z)\right) m_{x}^{*}(x, z)=v_{x x x}\left(x, z, m^{*}(x, z)\right)
$$

which implies that $v_{x x x}$ is continuous in boundary of $\mathcal{D}$. By applying similar calculation to the other third order partial derivatives of function $v$, we know $v(x, z, m) \in C^{3}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}\right)$. For any $t>0$, using Itô's rule to $Y_{t}=v_{x}\left(X_{t}^{*}, Z_{t}, M_{t}^{*}\right)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{t}= & Y_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} v_{x x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)\left(\theta_{s}^{*}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)\right)^{\top} \sigma d W_{s}+\int_{0}^{t} \sigma_{Z} Z_{s}\left(v_{x z}-v_{x x}\right)\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d W_{s}^{\gamma} \\
& +\int_{0}^{t} v_{x x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d L_{s}^{X}+\int_{0}^{t} \mathcal{L}^{\theta_{s}^{*}, c_{s}^{*}} v_{x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d s+\int_{0}^{t} v_{x m}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d M_{s}^{*, c} \\
& +\sum_{0<s \leq t} e^{-\rho s}\left(v_{x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)-v_{x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s-}^{*}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $M^{*}, c$ is the continuous part of $M^{*}$. Note that, the process $M^{*}$ can only jump at time $t=0$ if $m<m^{*}(x, z)$, then $\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)$ stays in the domain $\mathcal{D}$ for all $s>0$. In view that $M_{s}^{*, c}$ increases if and only if $M_{s}^{*, c}=m^{*}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}\right), v_{m}\left(x, z, m^{*}(x, z)\right)=0$ and (4.6) holds, we deduce

$$
\int_{0}^{t} e^{-\rho s} v_{x m}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d M_{s}^{*, c}+\sum_{0<s \leq t} e^{-\rho s}\left(v_{x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)-v_{x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s-}^{*}\right)\right)=0
$$

By Lemma 4.2, Lemma 4.3 and $W_{t}^{\gamma}=\gamma^{\top} W_{t}$, we can obtain that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{t}\left(v_{x x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)\left(\theta_{s}^{*}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right)\right)^{\top} \sigma d W_{s}+\sigma_{Z} Z_{s}\left(v_{x z}-v_{x x}\right)\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d W_{s}^{\gamma}\right) \\
& \quad=-\int_{0}^{t} \mu^{\top} \sigma^{-1} v_{x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d W_{s}=-\int_{0}^{t} \mu^{\top} \sigma^{-1} Y_{s} d W_{s} \\
& \int_{0}^{t} \mathcal{L}^{\theta_{s}^{*}, c_{s}^{*}} v_{x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d s=\int_{0}^{t} \rho v_{x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d s=\int_{0}^{t} \rho Y_{s} d s
\end{aligned}
$$

Denote $L_{t}^{Y}:=-\int_{0}^{t} v_{x x}\left(X_{s}^{*}, Z_{s}, M_{s}^{*}\right) d L_{s}^{X}$ for $t \geq 0$. Consequently, it follows from (A.1)-(A.4) that

$$
d Y_{t}=\rho Y_{t} d t-\mu^{\top} \sigma^{-1} Y_{t} d W_{t}-d L_{t}^{Y}, \quad t>0
$$

Noting that $v_{x}(x, z, m) \leq \beta, v_{x}(0, z, m)=\beta$ and $v_{x x}(x, z, m) \leq 0$ for all $(x, z, m) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{3}$, we have that the process $L=\left(L_{t}^{Y}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ is a continuous and non-decreasing process (with $L_{t}^{Y}=0$ ) which increases on the time set $\left\{t \geq 0 ; Y_{t}=\beta\right\}$ only. This implies that $Y$ taking values on $(0, \beta]$ is a reflected process and $L^{Y}$ is the local time process of $Y$.

Lemma A.3. Let $\mu_{Z} \geq \eta$ and $\rho>\rho_{0}$. Consider the reflected process $Y=\left(Y_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ defined in Lemma A.2. Then, we have

$$
\limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T} \mathbb{E}\left[Y_{T}^{\frac{p}{p-1}}\right]=0
$$

Proof. For the case $p<0$, the result obviously holds as $Y_{T}^{\frac{p}{p-1}} \leq \beta^{\frac{p}{p-1}}$ a.s., for all $T \geq 0$. In what follows, we only consider the case $p \in(0,1)$.

For $t \geq 0$, let $H_{t}=\beta Y_{t}^{-1}$, then by using Itô's rule to $H_{t}$, we can deduce that $H_{t}$ taking values on $[1, \infty)$ is a reflected process satisfies the following SDE with reflection:

$$
d H_{t}=(\alpha-\rho) H_{t} d t+\mu^{\top} \sigma^{-1} H_{t} d W_{t}+d L_{t}^{H}
$$

where the process $L=\left(L_{t}^{H}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ is the local time process which is continuous and non-decreasing with $L_{t}^{H}=0$ and increases on the time set $\left\{t \geq 0 ; H_{t}=1\right\}$ only. Then we can see

$$
0 \leq \limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T} \mathbb{E}\left[Y_{T}^{\frac{p}{p-1}}\right]=\limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T} \beta^{\frac{p}{p-1}} \mathbb{E}\left[H_{T}^{\frac{p}{1-p}}\right] \leq \limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T} \beta^{\frac{p}{p-1}} \mathbb{E}\left[H_{T}^{\frac{p^{\prime}}{1-p^{\prime}}}\right]
$$

where $p^{\prime}:=\max \{2 / 3, p\}$. If fact, $\rho \geq \max \left\{2 \alpha, p^{\prime} \alpha /\left(1-p^{\prime}\right)\right\}$ is equivalent to $\rho \geq \max \{2 \alpha, p \alpha /(1-$ p) $\}$, thus it is sufficient to deal with the case where $p \in[2 / 3,1)$. Noting that $h \leq 2 h-2$ when $h \geq 2$, then it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T} \mathbb{E}\left[Y_{T}^{\frac{p}{p-1}}\right] & \leq \limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T} \beta^{\frac{p}{p-1}} \mathbb{E}\left[2^{\frac{p}{1-p}}+\left(2 H_{T}-2\right)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}\right] \\
& =\limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T}\left(\frac{\beta}{2}\right)^{\frac{p}{p-1}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(H_{T}-1\right)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Using Itô's rule to $\left(H_{T}-1\right)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}$ and taking expectation, we obtain from $\rho \geq p \alpha /(1-p)$ that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(H_{T}-1\right)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}\right] \leq\left(H_{0}-1\right)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}+\frac{p(2 p-1) \alpha}{(1-p)^{2}} \int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[H_{t}\left(H_{t}-1\right)^{\frac{3 p-2}{1-p}}\right] d t
$$

If $p=2 / 3$ (i.e., $3 p-2=0$ and $p /(1-p)=2$ ), then the estimate (A.5) becomes

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(H_{T}-1\right)^{2}\right] \leq\left(H_{0}-1\right)^{2}+3 \alpha T+\alpha \int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(H_{t}-1\right)^{2}\right] d t
$$

It follows from (A.6) and the Gronwall's lemma that, for all $T \geq 0$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(H_{T}-1\right)^{2}\right] \leq\left(H_{0}-1\right)^{2}+3 \alpha T+\frac{1}{\alpha}\left(\left(H_{0}-1\right)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}-3\right)\left(e^{\alpha T}-1\right)+3 T e^{\alpha T}
$$

This yields that, for $\rho>\alpha p /(1-p)>\alpha$,

$$
\limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T} \mathbb{E}\left[Y_{T}^{\frac{p}{p-1}}\right] \leq \limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T}\left(\frac{\beta}{2}\right)^{\frac{p}{p-1}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(H_{T}-1\right)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}\right]=0
$$

On the other hand, if $p>2 / 3$ (i.e., $3 p-2>0$ ), we have that, for $h \geq 1$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
h(h-1)^{\frac{3 p-2}{1-p}} & =(h-1)^{\frac{2 p-1}{1-p}}+(h-1)^{\frac{3 p-2}{1-p}} \leq \max \left\{\frac{p}{1-p}, h-1\right\}^{\frac{3 p-1}{1-p}}+\max \left\{\frac{p}{1-p}, h-1\right\}^{\frac{3 p-2}{1-p}} \\
& \leq\left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)^{\frac{2 p-1}{1-p}}+\frac{(h-1)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}}{\frac{p}{1-p}}+\left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)^{\frac{3 p-2}{1-p}}+\frac{(h-1)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}}{\left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)^{2}} \\
& =\left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)^{\frac{2 p-1}{1-p}}+\left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)^{\frac{3 p-2}{1-p}}+\frac{1-p}{p^{2}}(h-1)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from (A.5) and (A.7) that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(H_{T}-1\right)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}\right] \leq\left(H_{0}-1\right)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}+C T+\frac{(2 p-1) \alpha}{1-p} \int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(H_{t}-1\right)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}\right] d t\right.
$$

where $C>0$ is a constant independent of $\rho$. In a similar fashion, by using Gronwall's lemma to (A.8) and noting $\rho>p \alpha /(1-p) \geq(2 p-1) \alpha /(p-1)$, we deduce that

$$
\limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T} \mathbb{E}\left[Y_{T}^{\frac{p}{p-1}}\right] \leq \limsup _{T \rightarrow \infty} e^{-\rho T}\left(\frac{\beta}{2}\right)^{\frac{p}{p-1}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(H_{T}-1\right)^{\frac{p}{1-p}}\right]=0
$$

Thus, we complete the proof of the lemma.

abstract:
This paper studies an optimal consumption problem with both relaxed benchmark
tracking and consumption drawdown constraint, leading to a stochastic control
problem with dynamic state-control constraints. In our relaxed tracking
formulation, it is assumed that the fund manager can strategically inject
capital to the fund account such that the total capital process always
outperforms the benchmark process, which is described by a geometric Brownian
motion. We first transform the original regular-singular control problem with
state-control constraints into an equivalent regular control problem with a
reflected state process and consumption drawdown constraint. By utilizing the
dual transform and the optimal consumption behavior, we then turn to study the
linear dual PDE with both Neumann boundary condition and free boundary
condition in a piecewise manner across different regions. Using the smoothfit
principle and the super-contact condition, we derive the closed-form solution
of the dual PDE, and obtain the optimal investment and consumption in feedback
form. We then prove the verification theorem on optimality by some novel
arguments with the aid of an auxiliary reflected dual process and some
technical estimations. Some numerical examples and financial insights are also
presented.
